column15: Notes
Algeria's app was investigated by Amnesty International.
Australian experts have criticized the government for a lack of transparency and non-responsiveness to privacy issues.
Austria was one of the first major European nations to align with the Google/Apple API.
Though 25% of the country has downloaded BeAware, there is little public information about the app.
The Belgium app is set to be released by September.
Bulgaria launched thier app in early April and began lifting movement restrictions in early May.
Canada's app is set to role out in Ontario in July, and expand to the rest of the country by late summer.

column3: Alipay, Hangzhou‰Ûªs Communist Party, Chinese national gov't
column15: There is very little information available to the public about how China's technology works.

column3: Research Centre of Excellence on Information and Communication Technologies (RISE)
column15: The Cypriot app was one of the earliest efforts to launch, all the way back in February.
eRouska is one part of the Czech government‰Ûªs larger "smart quarantine" plan
Smittestopp is temporarily deactivated as of June 16th and all data collected to that point deleted due to security concerns

column3: Bytelogics, Cybernetica, Fujitsu Estonia, Guardtime, Icefire, Iglu, Mobi Lab, Mooncascade, Velvet
column15: The Estonia government is planning to launch an app that will leverage DP-3T and the Google/Apple API by August.
CareFiji launched at the end of June and is modeled after the Singapore app TraceTogether.

column3: "Public private collaboration" National Cyber Security Center
column15: The Finnish government has proposed a bill to allow for the release of the app. If approved, Ketju will launch in August.
Like the UK and Norway, France negotiated with Apple and Google but decided against using their standards.
Germany opted for the Google/Apple API after initially aiming to build a centralized system.

column3: Ghana Health Services, Iquent, Ascend Technologies
column15: Ghana's app is focused on collecting users' location data.

column3: HM Government of Gibraltar and the Gibraltar Health Authority
column15: Gibralter's app launched on June 18th and over 25% of the population has downloaded it.

column3: Ministry of Innovation and Technology, NextSense
column15: The voluntary app alerts people who came within 2m of an infected person for at least 20min.

column3: Iceland‰Ûªs civil protection and emergency management team
column15: Iceland decided not to use Bluetooth because it was too unreliable and instead uses location data
India is the only democracy making its app mandatory for millions of people.

column3: Ministry of Communication and Information Technology (Kominfo) and the Ministry of SOEs
column15: The Indonesian app uses individuals' location data to cross reference telecommunications provider data.

column3: Network of academics, mostly from Sharif University of Technology
column15: Iran's original AC19 covid app was banned by Google Play for collecting more data than its rules allowed.
Unlike neighboring UK, Ireland opted to use the Google/Apple API
Officials said the app is not sufficiently accurate because it is based only on GPS and voluntary information.
After China, Italy was the first Western nation devastated by covid-19. They launched thier app in early June.
Japan's app has riddled with issues since it launched, and has been suspended at least twice.
A recent Amnesty International report highlighted Kuwait's app as one of the most invasive in the world.

column3: Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation
column15: The Malaysian app is available only on Android. The government has promised to publish the open source code.
The specific privacy and data policies for the Mexican app are currently quite thin and vague.
New Zealand's app is based on a check-in system using QR codes in public areas.
Android and iOS apps were launched in mid-April.
Northern Ireland has announced a deal with the same developer as Ireland's app.
On June 16th, Norway put a pause on the app and deleted all user data because security concerns and criticisms.
The app launched in April and has serious privacy concerns which sparked a letter demanding better protections from major organizations.
ProteGO is modeled after effots in Singapore.
The app is mandatory for all citizens and requires access to photos. It also had a major security breach upon launched.

column3: Ministry of Health and the Saudi Data and Artificial Intelligence Authority
column15: Tawakkalna app pairs with Tabaud, the contact tracing app, and allows citizens to request "movement permits" for mobility around the city.

column3: Ministry of Health and the Saudi Data and Artificial Intelligence Authority
column15: Tabaud is the contact tracing app of many Saudi applications trying to contain covid-19.
TraceTogether was the first major Bluetooth contact tracing app.

column3: Swiss National Covid-19 Science Task Force
column15: Initially, the Swiss opted to use DP-3T instead of the Google/Apple API. Now it looks they will be using both.
Thailand paired the proximity contact tracing app with a QR code check-in system, called Thai Chana
Tunisia's government says the app will remain voluntary so long as download rates are high.
Turkey mandates people who test positive download the app and can then share data with police.
The app is mostly decentralized, but citizens can be fined for refusing install or register for the app.
The UK has made headlines for its refusal to adopt the Google/Apple API. It now maybe considering a switch. It will launch in winter.
Vietnam is using a decentralized system but requires access to contacts and other media on mobile devices like photos.
